This film is a very solid, spooky, and engaging take on a classic story.I think it's very interesting to see people complain about an unanswered question the movie poses, since people have been arguing about that aspect of the book for over a century. I think that to write the film off because it's ambiguous is missing the point.Mackenzie Davis shines in this film, and the rest of the cast is great, too. The production design is perfect and charming, and the cinematography is striking and at times pretty inventive.We used to get a lot of gothic ghost stories, but they've been much less popular in the last couple decades, and most of what we've seen has been pretty bad. This movie is a gem in that respect -- a good haunted house movie.My one complaint is that I think they may have cut some interesting stuff, perhaps to secure a PG-13 rating, which is disappointing. There are things in the trailer that don't make it into the film. Either way, it flies by, and I would have liked to have spent some more time in this world.

Except they did it better.This has really bad acting and relies on really cliched scares movies from 40 years ago did better (e.g. Humanoid mannequins moving). I know it sounds cool but it ain't... It's just an actual mannequin in one scene, and OBVIOUSLY a woman in makeup in the other, turning her head. Which reminds me - I forgot to mention the few "effects" there are, are bad also.But hey, it's not all bad. Finn Wolfhard is as great as ever, and the woman playing the creepy housekeeper is perfect for that role. The rest of the cast is either terrible or aggressively generic. And as generic as the whole movie is, it does pick up steam halfway through, albeit with shallow jumpscares with no substance. It's so generic, in fact, that at one point the little hand from The Addams Family shows up for a pointless jumpscare... Nothing makes sense. The house is haunted - go wild, I guess. Eh...And the ending was kinda cool. In fact, the most original thing about this movie. So, for having the balls to at least change that up - 5/10.

I hate to make the assumption "ran out of ideas and rushed to an ending" in a serious context, but that seems to literally be the case here.
A whole lot of (spoilerrific) explanation seems to be going on in particular in IMDB's "Trivia" section, and while it all sounds well thought out, it has to be regarded as BS because there is simply nothing in the movie that even remotely hints at something like this.
The film as it unfolds is a fairly straightforward "babysitter in a haunted house with a pair of weird kids" formula, and does so with some genuine tension and intrigue.
This constitutes a full 95% or more of the film. The remaining less than 5% is also fairly straightforward and is pretty much just "Kate meets with her mother in an asylum, talks to her former roommate to vent".
There is simply nothing, either overtly or covertly, that can be interpreted to mean anything other than what the rest of the film is. As such, the ending, what ever it was trying to pull, did not come out of anything in the film itself.
As an example this would be the equivalent of a story of a woman buying a car, driving it around her neighborhood, pulling into her house, and walking in on her husband cheating on her, then going mad and killing him, only for the revelation that she actually died in a car accident as soon as she bought the new car.
It just does not follow. It is a complete and total non sequitur of an ending that really makes the "second movie of 2020 to receive an "F" cinemascore" make that much more sense.

reviews.review_title: Decent But Sloppily Executed Plot Twist
reviews.content: I wonder if this movie had any test screenings because if it hadn't, I'm pretty sure it would have benefited from them. The plot twist is where I felt this movie had its biggest flaw. The movie was not perfect prior to it. It used the same tropes a lot of mainstream horror movies have such as setups for jump scares and objects moving even when they don't really contribute to the story. Its 90s references were unnecessary and I barely even noticed them. However, I was actually enjoying the movie. The cast is solid, the little girl was a standout, and the plot became more intriguing as it went along. The movie held my attention and I was never really bored.And then came the plot twist. Its reveal was oddly abrupt and felt rushed. If the movie had rewrites, the twist probably could have been integrated into the plot much better. However, I think the movie would have been just fine without a plot twist because the climax that preceded the plot twist was actually pretty solid and entertaining. It felt as if there was an ending they filmed but they decided to cut it and insert a plot twist before said ending was shown. The plot twist made a lot of the setup and backstory feel pointless.I did not hate this movie anywhere near as much as a lot of people did but it would have been better if it weren't for its plot twist. The movie had a lot of interesting ideas but they were all let down by the end.

reviews.review_title: Leaves the plot with so many holes that ruins the experience
reviews.content: The Turning (2020) is based on the book The Turn of the Screw by Henry James. As of the time of this review, I have not read the novella, but it is on my to-do list. This review focuses solely on the film experience.In The Turning, the plot involves Kate and the brothers Miles and Flora Fairchild, orphans who live in a secluded mansion far from society. Kate accepted the position of housekeeper as the former housekeeper tragically died. The Fairchild brothers' parents also tragically died. Hum...The plot is monotonous for a while. The presentation involves a series of expositions that should lead to the main complication, but it doesn't. Kate grew up without her parents, but we soon discover that she has a mother who is admitted to the strangest psychiatric hospital of all, after all, what mental hospital would leave its patients inside an empty swimming pool? Flora also doesn't have parents and that's the connection between Kate and her. However, the connection is weak. The movie wants to make it clear that this connection is natural and obvious, but it doesn't work so well.Flora has psychological problems because of her personal experiences. Her first interaction with Kate feels fake and forced, which leads us to believe that perhaps Flora is questionable. The film doesn't make that clear.The film introduces us to the horror element when Flora shows the house to Kate. "I don't walk around that part of the house," Flora says to Kate, referring to the east side of the mansion. The plot does not use this element to develop the story.Miles quickly steals the show. The plot that seemed to focus so much on Flora and Kate disappears and makes room for Miles and Kate's relationship. Flora, despite being in a poster version of the movie and appearing in several key scenes in the trailers, becomes secondary. This twist causes Kate's interaction with Flora to not gain the strength it should have to justify Kate's subsequent acts.Miles is the typical troubled son of a tycoon. reviews.review_title: Not Bad, Just a Bit Convoluted
reviews.content: The Turning is not your average horror movie. While it can't exactly be called a masterpiece, it's well-shot, well-acted, and for the most part, well-paced. Though at times it can fall into cliche territory, it mostly remains an ambiguous and bizarre film.Its strengths lie in the performances of the main actors, especially the performance from McKenzie Davis. She captures very well the sense of paranoia and slow mental decay that the movie tries to portray. Some great cinematography also adds to the film's dark, psychological vibe.The problems really show themselves in the plot and underlying structure (or lack thereof), specifically towards the last quarter of the movie. While I believe it was the intention of the director and writer to be strange and difficult to follow, I can't help but feel like this film could have been much better with a few changes and resolutions to the ending of the film. Couple this with a few easy-to-predict jump scares, and the movie just doesn't quite reach its potential.At the end of the day, this film is a unique and intriguing horror movie. It's definitely not for everyone, but those seeking a dark, psychological detour will probably view this one multiple times. It leaves much up to the imagination and leaves the viewer with many questions. If not an instant or cult classic, The Turning is at the very least a fun and intellectually challenging thriller.

reviews.review_title: Hammers all the subtlety out of the original, but worth a look if you can step it out of that shadow
reviews.content:
As a remake of The Turn Of The Screw/Les Innocents, this was distinctly heavyhanded and overwrought. The power in that original story is how much is left up to interpretation; is it a haunting or a descent into madness? Is it a supernatural horror or a psychological thriller? Just exactly *how* close were the dearly departed to the children in their care? And the harrowing darkness of that original ending lends the film entire much of its impact.
The Turn belabours too much to do an adaptation of that story tonal justice, while explaining too little to be a fair introduction of any new viewer to the tale.HOWEVER, that said; this is a reasonably high-quality distinctly post-2000s -style horror when taken on its own merit. The production values were fantastic throughout, performances nuanced and convincing, and the tension built deftly. The now-ubiquitous jump scare tool was used in good balance with genuinely effecting suspense, and after the initial introductory slow-burn, the pace, once it picks up, escalates frenetically by the minute - to point where the hectic whirl of events has the viewer completely along for the ride with our heroine in no longer knowing what's real or not.
It's certainly better-acted and more emotionally compelling than the bulk of its contemporary fare.So, the TL version is; if you're looking for a delicately-woven and slowly-played gothic horror with an ending of guttingly horrific tragedy, then look elsewhere.
If you're in the market for ghosts and gasps with some solid performances and a breakneck pace post-orientation, as well as a close-up portrait of a likeable protagonist rapidly degenerating under trying conditions, then you could do a lot worse.
It's well worth a bucket of popcorn on a weekday night.

reviews.review_title: A DISSERVICE TO HENRY JAMES' ORIGINAL MASTERPIECE
reviews.content: This movie, it, well, I can't put into words exactly why I felt it was one of the most abortive, senseless, maligned and unimaginably misdirected and written films I have ever seen.Firstly, my opinions are completely based on a comparison between this version of Henry James' Turning Of The Screw, and the 1961 version, The Innocents, starring Deborah Kerr. Other than the fact that they both share the same basic premises -- Governess is hired to look after and teach a pair of wealthy, privileged children, and becomes embroiled in a good vs. evil battle to possess the children's (the "innocents") souls.Besides those broad plot points, there is no resemblance between the original, brilliantly crafted by Jack Clayton (director), and this senseless, predictable and wholly unimaginative remake. The story veers so far from the original that whereas the original, to this day, remains one of the most chilling and provoking horror movies of all time,The Turning becomes an insult, a hollow deceit.The ending is absurdly random, and obviously nothing more than a misguided attempt by the director to force some kind of shocking "twist" to justify Universal calling it a "horror" film. More reprehensible still, is the claim that this movie is a re-imagining, or modern interpretation , or an alternate version of Henry James' horrific classic.I normally would not try to obliterate a film just because I did not personally enjoy it, but when a film as precious as The Innocents is smeared by what many modern audiences will have as their only source by which to form their ignorant assumptions that The Innocents is just another unwatchable Turning of The Screw miscarriage. So, what makes The Turning any more significant than another Hollywood example of settling for mediocrity? This -- because it will indirectly also cause those who see it with no desire, no motivation to see a film which was revelatory and groundbreaking Which in turn may lessen the future chances of a moviegoer to be transported and elevated and gain insights which allow us as a species to evolve and explore.And that's why I felt the need to hopefully reverse some of the damage The Turning has caused, by encouraging moviegoers to instead, rent, buy or stream The Innocents. Remind yourselves of what it feels like to be entertained. To be transported. And scared.

I've read the book, and I liked it, so I went into the movie kind of expecting it to be awful. It's a novel about ambiguity in so many ways, and that's a literary style not easy or maybe even possible to translate into film. From the previews, I expected the movie to be just elements of the book reworked into a basic horror film. What I liked is that the movie made an effort to retain the two possible readings of the book, and I appreciated that since it's what makes the book special. The acting was also pretty great. Although, the ending pretty much settled on a singular interpretation.To me, it seemed like they wanted to do a modern retelling, but that proved to be too difficult to write with today's easy access to communication. It's something to contend with in any modern horror - long gone are the days of being really isolated, an environment necessary for so many horror plots to succeed. So, it seemed that the filmmakers thought the next best thing would be to set the movie in the 90's. Don't get me wrong, I'm a product of the 90's and enjoy the nostalgic aesthetic, but for it to really work, there needs to be a reason to set something in the 90's other than it making the writing easier as it's the decade most recent since technology.I agree with many of these reviews - too many jump scares early on lost the suspense. To be fair, I understand why many viewers may feel unsatisfied with The Turning. It challenges the typical formula of a film: exposition, rising action, climax, and eventually a denouement, where unresolved matters are resolved & unanswered questions are answered. There was virtually no closure at the end, and a plot-twist was introduced instead. And some individuals simply do not enjoy movies that take a more unique approach, but that doesn't automatically deem the film bad. It may just mean those individuals don't want to have to think too hard. Personally, I quite enjoyed the unsettling & confusing nature of this film. It felt as if I was going mad alongside the main protagonist, Kate, and I wasn't sure who the true threat was. Was Miles trying to mess with her? Or was he being messed with too and they were both victims? Speaking of Miles, I truly believe he was the driving force that kept the story interesting. I thoroughly enjoyed the thrill of his unpredictable behaviour because it was nearly impossible to tell if it was due to mental illness and hormones, or if some greater force was afoot. It seemed like maybe a mixture of both. Overall, The Turning was NOT a horrendous film. It merely requires you to use your analytical skills to think deeper about what you saw, rather than handing you a straightforward conclusion tied up in a perfect bow. I admire the artistic direction and ambition of the film, so I will confidently say that I liked it, even if I may have my own minor critiques!

reviews.review_title: Was This Really The Final Product?
reviews.content: I consider myself to be a bit of a horror movie buff, and I love a classic gothic horror story. I have also seen a majority of adaptations of 'Turn of the Screw' and have thoroughly enjoyed them all for the most part. I had high hopes for this adaptation as well but oh boy was that a mistake.Despite having an all-star cast, and a seemingly fantastic crew, 'The Turning' leaves a lot to be desired. We start off with our main protagonist Kate who has a mentally ill mother, and has been hired as a live-in tutor for a young girl from a prominent family. After we meet the rest of the main characters which consisted of the young girl Flora, her older brother Miles, and their nanny/housekeeper Mrs. Grose. As you would expect as the films go on things get increasingly spooky but nothing ever really happens. We never understand why any of the characters are doing what they do.Miles seems like a very confused kid but we aren't ever aware as to why? I mean, yeah, his parents died and so did his mentor but he's not just an angry teenager. At times his behaviour is manipulative, demeaning, and cruel. It is never really explained and frankly inconsistent.Flora is your average creepy little girl in a horror movie. Honestly nothing special about the character in this adaptation despite the best efforts of the young actress who portrayed her.Mrs. Grose was another wildly inconsistent character. Starts off as an uptight but obviously loving caretaker of the family, and then turns into a cruel, demeaning, and morally questionable woman. No explanation as to why, it just is.Now as all the other reviews have pointed out already the ending really leaves you thinking "Wow. What a waste of my time!" Around the 8 minute mark you're left feeling excited and then abruptly disappointed. Out of nowhere the films take 100 steps backwards and the last 20 minutes is irrelevant.This film could have been so good but who ever wrote the ending, and the character development needs to find a different genre to focus on.

reviews.review_title: Ending was awful, left with more questions than I came in with.
reviews.content: Pros: The acting was good enough. The main character's actor, Mackenzie Davis really does sell that she is terrified, even if we really aren't. Brooklyn Pierce is loveable as Flora- much less annoying than Miles, played by Finn Wolfhard. This, plus IT and The Goldfinch, really cemented the range that Finn Wolfhard is capable of. Despite this, though, you can't help but be worried for both of the children. From the start, the movie raises some good intrigue.Cons: Sadly, most of these questions go unanswered. Why is the housekeeper so weird? We know she knew Quint killed Miss Jessel, and she then she killed Quint, but the reason to her odd devotion to the family remains unclear. What is going on with Miles? We never find out- it is implied he is possessed or influenced paranormally by the spirit of Quint, but it's also possible he's just a huge jerk. The movie really needed more time- it was too short for what it was. It felt like it was all buildup with next to no climax. Unfortunately a poor movie. If you want something with an old, large house, a complex mystery, and rich children, watch The Others. Much more worth your time. Finn Wolfhard fans (because I know you're here): if you want something paranormal with him in it, watch Ghostbusters: Afterlife or IT (2017). If you want something in which his character is no longer a sniveling nerd and rather an edgier character with dubious morals, watch The Goldfinch. If you were just watching for Finn it doesn't matter anyway.

reviews.review_title: Henry James is Rolling in His Grave
reviews.content: "The Turn of the Screw" was a chilling work of classic gothic literature; a twisting tale of madness and terror. It was model for all future horror stories. "The Turning," on the other hand... one can't say the same for it. Every unsettling, ambiguous plot point of "The Turn of the Screw" was exchanged for some cheap jump-scare or unnecessary display of mediocre CGI. Characters were completely changed simply for the sake of being superfluously creepy and thereby discarding any of their original substance. However, none of the frightening scenes from the book (for example, Quint on the stairs or looking in through the window) were used in the film. The only reference to the novella's ambiguity came from an unclear ending, which only confused the audience instead of encouraging them to discuss Kate's sanity and whether the house was actually haunted. In conclusion, this movie missed the point and Henry James deserved better.

The children's dramatic mood swings mirror the unstable narrator's own mood swings - between seeing the children as helpless targets of the "ghosts", to them being in leagues to purposefully torment her. The awful dream reveal at the end being the result of her desire to "save" the children from a threat that probably doesn't actually exist. However, none of this is made even slightly clear in only the movie, so the characterization is extremely jarring. I think the interpretation of the Quint/Jessel subplot was very interesting and it definitely added a dynamic the book didn't have, however I don't think it was explored nearly to the extent it deserved.As for the good, this movie is beautifully shot and the sets are truly stunning, I wish I could steal all of the furniture they used. reviews.review_title: Worst adaptation of The Turning of The Screw ever
reviews.content: That whirling sound that you hear is Henry James rolling in his grave. There are literary analysis that allow for the idea that the 'ghosts' in the story are figments of the governess' imagination and that she is indeed insane, the novel is a bit ambiguous. However you cannot present a ghost story, as is initially done here, and suddenly in the last scene decide that it is a psychological thriller. There is no preparation in the plot for the teacher being mentally unstable, her mother not withstanding. That interpretation is also not the common one and is a definite outlier. The director has to make me believe it and she did not.At the close of this film I sat with my mouth agape wondering what it was that I just saw. The acting was adequate but the direction confused, many too many jump thrills. The cinematography was too atmospheric and moody, the entire film had an air of discontinuity. Also, personal aside, if these kids are not possessed, then they need a colossal whipping. The pranks they pull and their sense of entitlement, encouraged by the cook, is not to be believed. This is not part of the the teacher's psychosis as you see the scenes in the film and interpretation always starts at what the director shows you.
